awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Impacts of Automated Vehicles on Traffic Flow Using Empirical Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Emerging automated vehicle (AV) technologies are likely to disrupt and transform our transportation system.  The vast number of studies on AV hinge upon assumptions on how AVs behave with respect to other vehicles.  Unfortunately, few of the assumptions can be empirically validated due to the absence of AVs. And yet, a critical component of AV technologies, the adaptive cruise control (ACC), has been used for over a decade and can be used to fill this gap.  The research aims to study how vehicles with ACC behave when interacting with other vehicles on the road. The research will provide important insights on the behaviors of AVs in the future. The understandings gained from this research will also have important implications in traffic management, transportation planning, and design of ACC vehicles and AV.  Additionally, this project will engage in a range of integrated research, educational and outreach activities, including sharing the ACC data with the research and practice community, developing educational modules, and K-12 outreach through summer camp. 

More specifically, the research will (i) collect empirical trajectory data of ACC vehicles of different car-makers and their counterparts, regular vehicles (RVs), and (ii) formulate car-following models that capture the similar and differentiating features of ACCs and RVs.  The project will focus on data collection and model estimation efforts using Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE). This enables the novel applications of statistical inference methods (e.g., the likelihood ratio test) to test various hypotheses to assess the differences and similarities among different ACC systems and between ACCs and RVs. In particular, the research will test if ACC systems from different car-makers differ from one another and from the RVs, and if they change substantially over time. Knowing this is important because it will dictate whether or not future research in this area has to focus on analyzing each individual carmaker, or if ACC systems will eventually converge towards human-like driving.   In the modeling efforts, the research will build a general stochastic model so that the behaviors of ACC vehicles and RVs can be reconciled.  The research will examine different variations of the distributions of the model components to specify the model(s) and use MLE for estimation of model parameters.  Additionally, the research will use the estimated model(s) of the tested ACCs to extrapolate the results to the general mixed traffic.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigates the impact of autonomous vehicles (AVs) on traffic flow using empirical data. The main focus is understanding the longitudinal control of AVs, i.e., Adaptive Cruise Control (ACC), of recent car models and their impact on traffic congestion.  

Specifically, we have collected empirical trajectory data of commercial ACC-equipped vehicles and investigated their behavior characteristics regarding  stability. By stability we mean, for instance, whether the speed of vehicles on a platoon will amplify or dampen a speed perturbation in the platoon lead vehicle. Unfortunately, we found that most existing ACC vehicles are string unstable, suggesting that congestion will be amplified along the platoon, i.e., a small perturbation of the leader will cause stop-go-waves . We also find that in long platoons, the oscillation amplitude tends to exacerbate very quickly, which forces incoming ACC vehicles to apply very strong braking followed by a strong acceleration. This can cause significant discomfort and safety hazards. 

The project also brings new insights into how AVs will change the traditional traffic flow theory, especially the fundamental diagram that describes the relationship between density and flow of a traffic stream. Like human-driven vehicles, ACC systems display a linear equilibrium spacing-speed relationship (within the range of available data) but the key parameters of these relationships can differ significantly from human-driven traffic depending on input settings. At the minimum ACC headway setting, equilibrium capacities in excess of 3500 vehicles per hour are observed, together with an extremely fast equilibrium wave speed of 100 kilometers per hour. These fast waves are unfamiliar to human drivers, and may pose a safety risk. The results also suggest that ACC jam spacing can be much larger than in human traffic, which reduces the network storage capacity. 

Beyond those empirical findings, the project also investigates the underlying mechanisms of ACC’s impact on congestion and proposes some new ACC designs aimed to improve traffic congestion. In an effort to explain the empirical observations, we dived into the codebase of an open-source ACC system and found that the low-level control (that actually moves the car) has a great impact on the overall string stability of the bi-level structured ACC system. We extended the current theory as well as the experiment method to justify this finding. To guarantee string stability to improve traffic congestion, it is suggested to fine-tune the low-level control against common environmental disturbances such as road grades or winds.  

To further address the string stability issue found in empirical observations, this project has also proposed a few congestion-mitigating ACC models, which are expected to learn from good human driving behaviors as well as well-established car-following models in the traffic flow theory. Notably, we incorporate driver relaxation or anticipation into ACC systems, and proposed a new family of MPCs based on the celebrated Newell’s car-following model. Those new MPC ACCs provide a simple and elegant solution to achieve string stability, and avoids the challenges in prediction tasks. The new ACC models are designed to be compatible with current ACC car models and most of them are experimentally tested on the road by the team.   

In summary, the project conducts experiments on existing commercial ACC products and provides evidence of why they amplify traffic congestion. To further understand such properties, we extended the current theory to explain the significance of low-level control on ACC’s string stability. In the end the project also proposes solutions to the current problem, where new ACC designs are presented that mainly learn from good human driving behaviors as well as tested car-following models in the traffic flow theory.
